awd_titl_txt: S&AS: INT: COLLAB: Goal-driven Marine Autonomy with Application to Fisheries Science and Management
awd_abstract_narration:
Marine robots can be used to accurately map and track marine life, leading to a better interpretation of variability and migration patterns that are important to fisheries managers in marine protected areas (MPAs).  Principles of engineering and oceanography can be used to maximize the impact of a network of marine robots, but because fisheries managers, oceanographers, and roboticists have different perspectives and knowledge bases, it can be difficult to take advantage of cutting-edge research in each field without significant effort to translate among the groups. Researchers will develop a computational interface that translates human-specified missions of fisheries managers into multi-level planning for a fleet of marine robots to monitor fish populations in a dynamic coastal ocean environment. The system will be designed with input from fisheries managers through a series of workshops, and will be field-tested at Gray's Reef National Marine Sanctuary, a federally-managed MPA off the coast of Georgia.  The research will lead to more accurate and effective ways to monitor fish populations in MPAs, as well as breakthroughs in key areas of artificial intelligence and autonomous systems. Many of the results will be applicable to other smart and autonomous systems in challenging environments.  In addition, the project will train graduate students and broaden undergraduate education in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM), and offer a number of outreach activities, including working with the University of Georgia Marine Extension service to develop a summer camp for middle and high school students.

The project is focused on developing an intelligent physical system (IPS) that consists of a heterogeneous fleet of marine robots, cooperatively tracking fish movement and surveying the habitat with minimum request for human intervention. The IPS will translate the human-specified missions of fisheries managers into goal-driven task designs for each robot, and automatically generate executable plans for the networked mobile sensing agents. The system will autonomously and persistently collect in-situ measurements and acoustic detections of fish species while maintaining multi-scale data streams and constructing multiple spatial-temporal maps reflecting the conditions of the ecosystem. The research aims to discover the hotspots (e.g., spatial locations with sustained congregations of fish), as well as illuminate more information about how and when fish move among these hotspots. This goal is quite challenging due to a number of gaps between project needs and the state-of-art autonomy research. Researchers will address the challenges through new developments that accomplish three main tasks: (1) Developing the goal-driven marine autonomy for fish habitat survey, (2) realizing the goal-driven autonomy on physical systems, and (3) evaluating the developed framework through real-life field work, experiments, and data analysis.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The real-world application of fish tracking at the Gray?s Reef National Marine Sanctuary (GRNMS), a challenging coastal oceanic proving ground, serves as inspiration for breakthroughs in key areas of AI and autonomous systems.  The project develops fundamental research to enable an intelligent physical system (IPS), which features the integration of complex, functional software and hardware components that rely upon a high degree of independence when interacting with a demanding, physical environment in GRNMS.  Using autonomous mapping and tracking of marine life as a running example, the goal of this project is to develop and evaluate a goal-driven autonomy (GDA)-based framework for enabling a robust and flexible IPS that effectively addresses unexpected situations present in highly complex environments. The results developed in this project enables an IPS (1) to recognize problems in its environment; (2) to formulate new goals that remove problems; and (3) to change or otherwise manage the goals for broad missions.

 

The Georgia Tech team formed close collaborations with Michigan State University, University of Georgia, and Wright State University teams to achieve convergence of research ideas and coordination of research activities. The team has formulated goal-driven planning problems based on acoustic telemetry data and glider sensory data.  For system integration, the team have integrated a cognitive architecture (MIDCA) with a robotic planning software (GENIoS). The Georgia Tech team developed solutions for intelligent planning problems that handles uncertainties better than conventional methods.  The work converts difficult problems in continuous dynamics into easier problems in symbolic dynamics that can be solved by symbolic planning tools.  This opens the gate for goal-driven planning tools such as MIDCA to interface with the continuous dynamics to perform goal selection, goal change and formulation of new goals. One major contribution of our research is the characterization of the accuracy associated with the conversion from continuous dynamics to symbolic dynamics.  

The team solved two goal-driven planning problem that integrates all components of the proposed work. The first is a problem of searching for hotspots of high fish concentration while staying in a bounded region. The second is a problem of replanning after the detection of abnormal vehicle conditions under unknown ocean current. An IPS will be able to translate the vaguely specified goals in both problems to a set of predicates and actions that are computable with MIDCA and GENIoS. Both problems are now integrated, and simulation results demonstrated robustness in a dynamic environment. We also explored the situation of distributed planning and information collection. This involved the incorporation of symbolic based communication among the intelligent agents. The Georgia Tech team is bridging the gap between the high-level reasoning and the lower-level planning and control by addressing the key problems that arise from the abstraction, which include accuracy, robustness, and computational complexity. These problems are general problems for smart and autonomous systems.

 

With a long history partnership with GRNMS and guidance from the fisheries community
throughout the project, the products of this research will facilitate the evaluation of areas of connectivity outside of MPAs, which have been proven as an effective way to manage and sustain marine fisheries. The computational procedures to mapping and tracking acoustic fish distribution could be applied to a broad scope of environmental problems such as tracking pollutants and debris. Our research represents a novel perspective towards improving the accuracy of predictions, building on recent interdisciplinary advances at the intersection of robotics and marine ecology. We have published a chapter in a recent book reviewing all scientific effort carried at the GRNMS, demonstrating the impact of this project.

 

Two Georgia Tech PhD students, including one female student, have been working on this project. They have received joint advice from co-PIs Mike Cox and Catherine Edwards.  A student is expected to graduate August, 2022 with a Ph.D. degree.
